messageBody:
Read did set standards for certain prefixes and suffixes, fully expecting standards to
develop for others. (His can be found in the Quikscript Manual, by the way.) There
really hasn't been much standardization, though it's a good idea.
The solution that's been proposed for Shavian is to define the sounds of letters with
sample words and to allow the writer to use the letter as (s)he pronounces it in that
particular word. Since sound changes are fairly uniform throughout any dialect, this
should still represent the same phoneme. For example, we could say that /E/
represents the vowel found in "day", and it will always be used for that phoneme, no
matter how you actually pronounce it. If your dialect says [F], you still write /E/, and
you do it consistently. Australians will just learn a different sound-sign assignment
and pronounce it their way unless they're speaking in a different accent.
I've also found that since I've learned Quikscript and Shavian, my knowledge of
English phonology has increased and my pronunciation has changed with it. It's my
hope that, in the same way, standardizing spelling will help to standardize
pronunciation as well.
If you think about it, it's already based on British English. The letters are designed to
represent the phonemes of the dialect of George V, and their form reflects a standard
pronunciation, even it this is not the one used in other dialects.
But whatever dialect it's based on, I think we can all accept standard spellings if we
write phonemes instead of phones and are allowed to pronounce them as we wish.
Maybe we should work together to compile a list of morphemes (word parts) with
standard spellings. I'm reminded of an article on the value of morphemic spelling,
which you can find here: http://www.spellingsociety.org/journals/j2/gregersen.html
It's an interesting idea, and worth consideration. That said, I think I'll sleep on it. I
stay up way to late...

--- In Read_Alphabet@yahoogroups.com, "cossyrosario" <cossyrosario@y...> wrote:
>
>
> Correct me if I'm wrong, but I get the impression that Quikscript has
> developed standard Quikscript spellings based on American
> pronunciations.
>
> I speak British English, although I'm perfectly comfortable hearing
> American English. When it comes to spontaneously writing Quikscript,
> however, I write the British way, and have had cause for pause while
> reading examples of Quikscript spelt the American way. Of course, the
> difficulty lasts just a moment, but the experience gave rise to the
> reflection that one of the factors that makes English a worldwide
> language is that the spelling (however atrociously complicated and
> irregular) is understood all over the English-using world, (despite
> discrepancies betwen Ameican and English spellings). Differences in
> pronunciation don't come in the way. For example, while I find it hard
> to understand Australian speech, I have no problems with Australian
> English as expressed in newspapers or internet sites.
>
> I remember the story of the Australian who woke up in a hospital bed
> and saw a friend in the next bed. He asked, "Did you come here to
> die?" Replied his friend, "Yes, to die!" For any who have never heard
> an Australian speaking, the dialogue went thus: "Did you come here
> today?" "Yesterday."
>
> Imagine an Australian writing the words "today" and "yesterday" in
> Quikscript the way he pronounces it! Neither the Englishman nor the
> American would be likely to guess what it means.
>
> What do you feel about standardizing Quikscript spellings to the sound
> of British English? The argument in favor would be that it is
> understood in all the former British colonies, probably including the
> USA.
